scenes.location: SOUTH BOSTON ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. L STREET BAR & GRILLE, SOUTH BOSTON -- EVENING The bar is dirty, more than a little run down. If there i ever a cook on duty, he's not here now. As we pan across  several empty tables, we can almost smell the odor of las nights beer and crushed pretzels on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I got the most fucked up  thing I been meanin' to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the camera rises, we find FOUR YOUNG MEN seated around table near the back of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus. Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy holding court is CHUCKIE SULLIVAN, 20, and the la of the bunch. He is loud, boisterous, a born entertainer. Next to him is WILL HUNTING, 20, handsome and confident, softspoken leader. On Will's right sits BILLY MCBRIDE, 22 heavy, quiet, someone you definitely wouldn't want to tan with. Finally there is MORGAN O'MALLY, 19, smaller than the oth guys. Wiry and anxious, Morgan listens to Chuckie's horro stories with eager disgust. All four boys speak with thick Boston accents. This is a  rough, working class Irish neighborhood and these boys ar its product.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys know my cousin Mikey  Sullivan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you know how he loves animals  right?  Anyway, last week he's drivin'  home... (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying not to laugh) I'm sorry, 'cause you know Mikey,  the fuckin guy loves animals, and  this is the last person you'd want  this to happen to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie, what the fuck happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. He's driving along and this  fuckin' cat jumps in front of his  car, and so he hits this cat--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie is really laughing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --That isn't funny--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and he's like "shit! Motherfucker!" And he looks in his rearview and  sees this cat -- I'm sorry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' Chuckie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he sees this cat tryin to make it  across the street and it's not lookin'  so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's walkin' pretty slow at this  point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are fuckin' sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Mikey's like "Fuck, I gotta put  this thing out of its misery"--So he  gets a hammer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: out of his tool box, and starts  chasin' the cat and starts whackin'  it with the hammer. You know, tryin'  to put the thing out of its misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all the time he's apologizin' to  the cat, goin' "I'm sorry." BANG,  "I'm sorry." BANG!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like it can understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this Samoan guy comes runnin'  out of his house and he's like "What  the fuck are you doing to my cat?!"  Mikey's like "I'm sorry" --BANG--" I  hit your cat with my truck, and I'm  just trying to put it out of it's  misery" -- BANG! And the cat dies.  So Mikey's like "Why don't you come  look at the front of the truck." 'Cause the other guy's all fuckin  flipped out about--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching his cat get brained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan gives Will a look, but Will only smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so he's like "Check the front  of my truck, I can prove I hit it  'cause there's probably some blood  or something"--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --or a tail--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILL!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so they go around to the front  of his truck... and there's another  cat on the grille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Ugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that unbelievable? He brained an  innocent cat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening credits roll over a series of shots of the ci and the real people who live and work there, going about  their daily lives. We see a panoramic view of South Boston. Will sits in his apartment, walls completely bare. A bed, small night table and an empty basket adorn the room. A s of twenty or so LIBRARY BOOKS sit by his bed. He is flipp through a book at about a page a second. Chuckie stands on the porch to Will's house. His Cadillac idles by the curb. Will comes out and they get in the car We travel across crowded public housing and onto downtown Finally, we gaze across the river and onto the great  cementdomed buildings that make up the M.I.T. campus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The classroom is packed with graduate students and TOM. PROFESSOR LAMBEAU (52) is at the lectern. The chalkboard  behind him is covered with theorems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please finish McKinley by next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many of you probably had this as undergraduates in real  analysis. It won't hurt to brush up. I am also putting an advanced fourier system on the main hallway chalkboard-- Everyone groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hoping that one of you might  prove it by the end of the semester.  The first person to do so will not  only be in my good graces, but go on  to fame and fortune by having their  accomplishment recorded and their  name printed in the auspicious "M.I.T.  Tech."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prof. Lambeau holds up a thin publication entitled "M.I.T Tech." Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Former winners include Nobel  Laureates, world renowned astro- physicists, Field's Medal winners  and lowly M.I.T.  professors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. That is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smattering of applause. Students pack their bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a monster indoor funpark. Will, Chuckie, Mor and Billy are in adjoining batting cages. Will has disabl the pitching machine in his and pitches to Chuckie. The b have been drinking. Will throws one to Chuckie, high and  tight. Several empty beer cans sit by the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pitch, inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna get charged!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm afraid of you, you big  fuck? You're crowdin' the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will guns another one, way inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop brushin' me back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop crowdin the plate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie laughs and steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casey's bouncin' at a bar up Harvard.  We should go there sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, we'll fuck up some  smart kids. (stepping back in) You'd prob'ly fit right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will fires a pitch at Chuckie's head. Chuckie dives to av being hit. He gets up and whips his batting helmet at Wil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAN McGUIRE (52) sits, FORMALLY DRESSED, on the roof of apartment building in a beat-up lawn chair. Well-built an fairly muscular, he stares blankly out over the city. On his lap rests an open invitation that reads "M.I.T. CL

dialogues.speaker: OF '67 REUNION."
dialogues.text: While the morning is quiet and Sean sits serenely, there a look about his that tells us he has faced hard times. T is a man who fought his way through life. On his lonely s we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thirty year REUNION PARTY has taken over the lawn. A we dressed throng mill about underneath a large banner that  reads "WELCOME BACK CLASS OF '72." We find Professor Lamb standing with a drink in his hand, surveying the crowd. H is interrupted by an approaching STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Professor Lambeau?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in your applied theories class. We're all down at the Math and Science  building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. We just couldn't wait 'till  Monday to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who proved the theorem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bleachers of the visiting section we find our boys drinking and smoking cigarettes. Will pops open a beer. T boys have been here a while and it shows. Billy sees something that catches his interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? She's got a nice ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their P.O.V. reveals a girl in stretch pants talking to a beefy looking ITALIAN GUY (BOBBY CHAMPA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, that is a nice ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could put a pool in that backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's she talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fuckin' guinea, Will knows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, Bobby Champa. He used to beat  the shit outta' me in Kindergarten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a pretty big kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, he's the same size now as he  was in Kindergarten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck this, let's get something to  eat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Morgan, you're not gonna go  talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys get up and walk down the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could go for a Whopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant) Let's hit "Kelly's."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan, I'm not goin' to "Kelly's  Roast Beef" just cause you like the  take-out girl. It's fifteen minutes  out of our way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else we gonna do we can't spare  fifteen minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Morgan, fine. I'll tell  you why we're not going to "Kelly's."  It's because the take-out bitch is a  fuckin' idiot. I'm sorry you like  her but she's dumb as a post and she  has never got our order right, never  once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sharp as a marble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not goin'. (beat) I don't even like "Kelly's."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau, still in his reunion formal-wear, strides down t hallway, carrying some papers. A group of students have  gathered by the chalkboard. They part like the red sea as approaches the board. Using the papers in hand, he checks the proof. Satisfied, he turns to the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is correct? Who did this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead silence. Lambeau turns to an INDIAN STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nemesh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nemesh shakes his head in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau erases the proof and starts putting up a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whoever You are, I'm sure you'll  find this one challenging enough to  merit coming forward with your  identity.  That is, if you can do  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is crowded as our boys drive down Broadway. Th move slowly through heavy traffic, windows down. Chuckie  sorts through a large "KELLY'S ROAST BEEF" BAG as he driv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Burger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will holds the wheel for Chuckie as he looks through the  bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same tone) Double Burger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie gets out fries for himself, hands Will his fries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, I had a Kelly's Double Burger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you shut the fuck up! I know  what you ordered, I was there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why don't you give me my sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean "your sandwich?" I  bought it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yah, all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much money you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I just got change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well give me your fuckin' change and  we'll put your fuckin' sandwich on  layaway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you gotta be an asshole Chuckie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should establish a good  line of credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter, Chuckie goes back searching through the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh motherfucker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't do it again did she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Not even close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she get my Double Burger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO SHE DIDN'T GET YOUR DOUBLE BURGER!! IT'S ALL FUCKIN' FLYIN' FISH FILET!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie whips a FISH SANDWICH back to Morgan, then to Bil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, that's really bad, did anyone  even order a Flyin' Fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, and we got four of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta' be kiddin' me. Why do we  even go to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause fuckin' Morgan's got a crush  on her, we always go there and when  we get to the window he never says a  fuckin' word to her, he never even  gets out of the car, and she never  gets our order right cause she's the  goddamn MISSING LINK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she out did herself today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't got a crush on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push in on Will who sees something O.S. Will's P.O.V. reveals BOBBY CHAMPA and his friends walkin down the street. One of them casually lobs a bottle into wire garbage can. It SHATTERS and some of the glass hits FEMALE PASSERBY who, although unhurt, is upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's P.O.V.: The woman says something to Bobby. He says something back. By the look on her face, it was something unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Will...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, why didn't you fight him at the  park if you wanted to? I'm not goin'  now, I'm eatin' my snack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) So don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is out of the door, jogging toward Bobby Champa. Bil gets out, following Will with a look of casual indifferen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan, Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious Chuckie, I ain't goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving the car, Chuckie opens his door to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spins in his seat) You're goin'. And if you're not out  there in two fuckin' seconds, when  I'm done with them you're next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Chuckie is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will comes jogging up towards BOBBY CHAMPA, calling out f across the street,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, good  naturedly) Hey, Bobby Champa! I went to  Kindergarten with you right? Sister  Margaret's class...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is bewildered by this strange interruption and unsu of Will's intentions. Just when it looks as though Bobby  might remember him, Will DRILLS HIM with a sucker-punch w begins the

dialogues.speaker: FIGHT SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Will's momentum and respectable strength serve to knock t hapless Champa out cold. As soon as Will hits Bobby, his friends CONVERGE ON WILL. Billy JUMPS IN and wrestles one guy to the ground. The tw exchange messy punches on the sidewalk. Will is in trouble, back pedaling, dodging punches, tryin to avoid being overrun. When Will goes for one guy, another has an open shot and HAMMERS WILL with a right hand to the head. Will is staggered and bleary, as a second guy winds up fo shot he is BLIND SIDED by Chuckie who hits the kid like h was a tackling sled, lifting him off the ground. Chuckie turns to see Will still outnumbered. It's all Wil can do to stay standing as Morgan DROP KICKS one of Champ boys from the hood of a car. Contrary to what we might think, Morgan is actually quite fighter. He peppers the kid with a flurry of blows. The fight is messy, ugly and chaotic. Most punches are th wildly and miss, heads are banged against concrete, someo throws a bottle. In the end, it's our guys who are left standing, while Bo friends stagger off. Chuckie and Morgan turn to see Will, standing over the unconscious Bobby Champa, still POUNDIN him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Whatever demons must be raging inside Will, he is taking  them out on Bobby Champa. He pummels the helpless, uncons Champa, fury in his eyes. Chuckie and Billy pull Will awa The POLICE finally arrive on the scene and having only  witnessed Will's vicious attack on Champa, they grab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of onlookers have gathered. Chuckie addresses the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks for comin' out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're all invited over to  Morgan's house for a complementary  fish sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police slam Will into the hood of a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Police) Hey, I know it's not a French cruller,  but it's free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop holding Will SLAMS his [Will's] face into the hoo another cop uses a baton to press Will's face into the ca The look of rage returns to Will's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will resists. Another cop comes over. Will KICKS HIM IN T KNEE, dropping the cop. Momentarily freed, Will engages i fracas with three cops. More converge on Will, who -- tho he struggles -- takes a beating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean sits, exactly as we first saw him, except his tie is now loose and an empty bottle of BUSHMILLS is at his side He stares out over the City. A MATRONLY LANDLADY comes ou of a doorway on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, she retreats back down the stairs. Sean  doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The morning sun reflects brilliantly off the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will emerges from the courthouse. Chuckie is waiting for in the Cadillac with two cups of DUNKIN' DOUGHNUTS coffee He hands one of them to Will. This feels routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the arraignment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Students walk to class, carrying bags. More than any othe students seem to be heading into one PARTICULAR CLASSROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The classroom is even more crowded than last we saw it. T takes notes as Lambeau plays along with the excited  environment with mock pomposity and good humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it my imagination, or has my class  grown considerably?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look around and see young people  who are my students, young people  who are not my students as well as  some of my colleagues. And by no  stretch of my imagination do I think  you've all come to hear me lecture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But rather to ascertain the identity  of who our esteemed "The Tech" has  come to call "The Mystery Math  Magician."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up the M.I.T. Tech featuring a silhouetted figur emblazoned with a large, white question mark. The headlin reads "Mystery Math Magician strikes again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever you are, you've solved four  of the most difficult theorems I've  ever given a class. So without further  ado, come forward silent rogue, and  receive thy prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class waits in breathless anticipation. A STUDENT shi his weight in his chair, making a noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry to disappoint my  spectators, but it appears there  will be no unmasking here today. I'm  going to have to ask those of you  not enrolled in the class to make  your escape now or, for the next  three hours be subjected to the  mundities of eigenvectors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People start to gather their things and go. Lambeau picks a piece of chalk and starts writing on the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, my colleagues and I have  conferred. There is a problem on the  board, right now, that took us two  years to prove. So let this be said;  the gauntlet has been thrown down.  But the faculty have answered the  challenge and answered with vigor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau comes out of his office with Tom and locks the do As he turns to walk down the hallway, he stops. A faint  TICKING SOUND can be heard. He turns and walks down the h Lambeau and Tom come around a corner. His P.O.V. reveals figure in silhouette blazing through the proof on the  chalkboard. There is a mop and a bucket beside him. As La draws closer, reveal that the figure is Will, in his jani uniform. There is a look of intense concentration in his  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will looks up, immediately starts to shuffle off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau follows Will down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name? (beat) Don't you walk away from me. This is  people's work, you can't graffiti  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) Well... I'll be speaking to your  supervisor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will walks out. Lambeau goes to "fix" the proof, scanning the blackboard for whatever damage Will caused. He stops, scans the board again. Amazement registers on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hall, we hear the DOOR CLOSE. He turns to look f Will, who is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded Harvard Bar. Will and our gang walk by a line o several Harvard students, waiting to be carded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? (beat) You got fired, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Morgan. I got fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts laughing) How fuckin' retarded do you have to  be to get shit-canned from that job?  How hard is it to push a fuckin'  broom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got fired from pushing a broom,  you little bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, that was different. Management  was restructurin'--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, restructurin' the amount of  retards they had workin' for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you fat fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least I work for a livin'. (to Will) Why'd you get fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Management was restructurin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My uncle can probably get you on my  demo team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck? I just asked you for  a job yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you "no" yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After two students flash their ID's to the doorman (CASEY our boys file past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (one after another) What's up Case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an imperceptible nod, Casey waves our boys through. fifth kid, a HARVARD STUDENT, tries to follow. He is stop by Casey's massive, outstretched arm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ID?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie is collecting money from the guys to buy a pitche all but Morgan cough up some crumpled dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this is a Harvard bar, huh? I  thought there'd be equations and  shit on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie returns to a table where Will, Morgan and Billy h made themselves comfortable. He [Chuckie] spots two ATTRA YOUNG HARVARD WOMEN sitting together at the end of the ba Chuckie struts his way toward the women and pulls up a ch He flashes a smile and tries to submerge his thick Boston accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you ladies ah, go to school here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, cause I think I had a class  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, several interested parties materialize. Mo Billy and Will try, as inconspicuously as possible, to si themselves within listening distance. A rather large stud in a HARVARD LACROSSE sweatshirt, CLARK (22) notices Chuc He [Clark] walks over to Skylar and Lydia, nobly hovering over them as protector. This gets Will, Morgan, and Billy attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, history I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, it's not a bad school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point, Clark can't resist and steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What class did you say that was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you like that course?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, it was all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History? Just "history?" It must  have been a survey course then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie nods. Clark notices Chuckie's clothes. Will and B exchange a look and move subtly closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty broad. "History of the World?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come on pal we're in classes  all day. That's one thing about  Harvard never seizes to amaze me,  everybody's talkin' about school all  the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm the last guy to want to  talk about school at the bar. But as  long as you're here I want to "seize"  the opportunity to ask you a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy shifts his beer into his left hand. Will and Morgan see this. Morgan rolls his eyes as if to say "not again..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sure you covered it in your  history class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark looks to see if the girls are impressed. They are n When Clark looks back to Chuckie, Skylar turns to Lydia a rolls her [own] eyes. They laugh. Will sees this and smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I wasn't there  much. The class was rather elementary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elementary? Oh, I don't doubt that  it was. I remember the class, it was  just between recess and lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Billy come forward, stand behind Chuckie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, are we gonna have a  problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no problem. I was just hoping  you could give me some insight into  the evolution of the market economy  in the early colonies. My contention  is that prior to the Revolutionary  War the economic modalities especially  of the southern colonies could most  aptly be characterized as agrarian  precapitalist and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, who at this point has migrated to Chuckie's side an is completely fed-up, includes himself in the conversatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course that's your contention.  You're a first year grad student.  You just finished some Marxian  historian, Pete Garrison prob'ly,  and so naturally that's what you  believe until next month when you  get to James Lemon and get convinced  that Virginia and Pennsylvania were  strongly entrepreneurial and  capitalist back in 1740. That'll  last until sometime in your second  year, then you'll be in here  regurgitating Gordon Wood about the  Pre-revolutionary utopia and the  capital-forming effects of military  mobilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Well, as a matter of fact, I won't,  because Wood drastically  underestimates the impact of--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wood drastically underestimates the  impact of social distinctions  predicated upon wealth, especially  inherited wealth..." You got that  from "Work in Essex County," Page  421, right? Do you have any thoughts  of your own on the subject or were  you just gonna plagiarize the whole  book for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, don't try to pass yourself off  as some kind of an intellect at the  expense of my friend just to impress  these girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark is lost now, searching for a graceful exit, any exi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sad thing is, in about 50 years  you might start doin' some thinkin'  on your own and by then you'll realize  there are only two certainties in  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What're those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, don't do that.  Two -- you  dropped a hundred and fifty grand on  an education you coulda' picked up  for a dollar fifty in late charges  at the Public Library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will catches Skylar's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I will have a degree, and you'll  be serving my kids fries at a drive  through on our way to a skiing trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Maybe. But at least I won't be a  prick. (beat) And if you got a problem with that,  I guess we can step outside and deal  with it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Will is substantially smaller than Clark, he [Clark decides not to take Will up on his [Will's] offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you change your mind, I'll be  over by the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away. Chuckie follows, throwing Clark look. Morgan turns to a nearby girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy's wicked smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits with Morgan at the bar watching with some amuse as Chuckie and Billy play bar basketball game where the  players shoot miniature balls at a small basket. In the B occasionally we hear Chuckie shouting "Larry!" When he sc Skylar emerges from the crowd and approaches Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been sitting over there for  forty-five minutes waiting for you  to come talk to me. But I'm just  tired now and I have to go home and  I wasn't going to keep sitting there  waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skylar. And by the way. That guy  over there is a real dick and I just  wanted you to know he didn't come  with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kind of got that impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look, I have to go. Gotta' get  up early and waste some more money  on my overpriced education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean you. Listen, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skylar produces a folded piece of paper and offers it to  Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could go out for coffee  sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, or maybe we could go somewhere  and just eat a bunch of caramels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you think about it, it's just  as arbitrary as drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Okay, sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to be smooth. (indicates clock) But at twelve-fifteen I was gonna  come over there and talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, it's my life story. Five more  minutes and I would have got to hear  your best pick-up line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caramel thing is my pick-up line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad I came over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boys are walking out of the bar teasing one another a their bar-ball exploits. Across the street is another bar with a glass front. Morgan spots Clark sitting by the win with some friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes that fuckin' Barney right  now, with his fuckin' "skiin' trip."  We should'a kicked that dude's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will crosses the street and approaches the plate glass wi and stands across from Clark, separated only by the glass He POUNDS THE GLASS to get Clark's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark turns toward Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DO YOU LIKE APPLES?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DO YOU LIKE APPLES?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will SLAMS SKYLAR'S PHONE NUMBER against the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WELL I GOT HER NUMBER! HOW DO YA  LIKE THEM APPLES?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's boys erupt into laughter. Angle on Clark, deflated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys make their way home, piled into Chuckie's car,  laughing together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of car crossing over the Charles St. Bridge, overtak a red-line train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traveling through narrow back roads in Charlestown, passi the Bunker Hill monument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arriving at Will's house and dropping him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau walks into a small garage facility. The area stor lawn machinery and various tools. An older man, TERRY (58 sits behind the desk reading the BOSTON HERALD sports pag Lambeau has obviously never been here before. He takes in the surroundings, somewhat uncomfortable. Gets dirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Is this the buildings and  grounds office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to find the name of a  student who works here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No students work for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you just check, because the  young man who works in my building--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one's your building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Building two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry checks a list behind his [own] desk. Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if something was stolen, I  should know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Nothing like that. I just  need his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give you his name unless you  have a complaint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I'm a professor here and  it's very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he didn't show up for work  today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry takes a beat. Holding all the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, he got his job through his  P.O. so you can call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry goes through a stack of paper on his desk. Takes ou card and hands it to Lambeau. Lambeau looks blankly at th card which reads: "PAROLE EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will stands before JUDGE MALONE (40) being arraigned. It fairly unceremonious, the courtroom nearly empty, save Wi and the PROSECUTOR. Lambeau walks in from the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a lengthy legal precedent,  Your Honor, going back to 1789,  whereby a defendant may claim self- defense against an agent of the  government where the act is shown to  be a defense against tyranny, a  defense of liberty--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge interrupts to address the prosecutor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Simmons, Officer McNeely who  signed the complaint isn't in my  courtroom. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the hospital with a broken  knee, Your Honor. But I have  depositions from the other officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry Ward Beecher proclaimed, in  his Proverbs From Plymouth Pulpit  back in 1887, that "Every American  citizen is by birth, a sworn officer  of the state.  Every man is a  policeman." As for the other officers,  even William Congrave said; "he that  first cries out 'stop thief' is 'oft  he that has stolen the treasure."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will cranks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Prosecutor) I am afforded the right to speak in  my own defense by our constitution,  Sir.  The same document which  guarantees my right to liberty.  "Liberty," in case you've forgotten,  is "the soul's right to breathe, and  when it cannot take a long breath  laws are girded too tight.  Without  liberty, man is a syncope." (beat, to Judge) Ibid. Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man is a what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julius Caesar proclaimed -- Though  he be wounded-- "Magna..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, (a beat) My turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge opens Will's CASE HISTORY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) June, '93, assault, Sept. '93  assault... Grand theft auto February  '94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, the Judge takes particular notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where, apparently, you defended  yourself and had the case thrown out  by citing "free property rights of  horse and carriage" from 1798...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau has to smile, impressed. The Judge shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March, '94 public drunkenness, public  nudity, assault. 10/94 mayhem.  November '94, assault. Jan. '95  impersonating a police officer,  mayhem, theft, resisting -- overturned--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge takes a beat. Gives Will a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in my courtroom, now and I am  aware of your priors. (beat) I'm also aware that you're an orphan.  You've been through several foster  homes. The state removed you from  three because of serious physical  abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge holds a look to Will, who looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Judge might care. You hit a  cop, you go in. (beat) Motion to dismiss denied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailiff goes to remove Will from the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep workin' on your arguments, son.  A word of advice for trial; speak  English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Will is removed from the courtroom, Lambeau approaches Judge Malone who is stepping down from the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, your Honor. (offers hand) Gerald Lambeau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward beat. Lambeau waits for some sign of recogniti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a professor at M.I.T. (beat) Combunatorial Mathematics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge offers only a blank look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD walks Will down a hallway toward a group of phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One call, to an attorney. (beat) One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard gives Will a hard look for a beat. Then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Skylar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Will, the really funny good  looking guy you met at the bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't recall meeting  anyone who fits that description.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you got me. It's the ugly,  obnoxious, toothless loser who got  drunk and wouldn't leave you alone  all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Will! I was wondering when you'd  call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I figured maybe sometime this  week we could go to a cafe and have  some caramels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good, where are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't, by any chance, Pre-law?  Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Lambeau sits, waiting. Will is brought in, shac by the guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Gerald Lambeau, M.I.T.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've spoken with the judge and he's  agreed to release you under my  supervision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes. Under two conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you meet with me twice a weekВ— (a beat) and you meet with a therapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I agree to this, I walk right  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do the work. I'm not going to  meet with a therapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, it won't be as bad as it sounds,  Will. (beat) I've already spoken to one therapist,  his name is Henry Lipkin and he's a  friend of mine. He's also published  four books and is widely considered  to be one of the brightest men in  his field. (beat) I'm sure it'll be better than spending  the next six months in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Chuckie walk up to an enclosed trampoline. Billy and Morgan prefer to use it for their own version of  "Wrestlemania." As Will and Chuckie approach, Billy is on top of a bloodi Morgan and has him in the "Cobra Clutch."  Will and Chuck watch for a beat. Billy tightens his grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Submit, bitch! Submit! Submit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (being strangled) Suck my cock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Morgan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie turns to Will, conspiratorially as they wait for fight to finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you get? You get leniency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probation, counselin', few days a  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fuckin' good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just submit, Morgan. He's got you in  the Cobra Clutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chuckie) Fuck your mother too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits alone in his one room apartment, reading. A clo look reveals he is reading a self-help PSYCHOLOGY BOOK. W is flipping through the book at about a page per second. shakes his head and smiles. Upon finishing the book, he t it in a nearby WASTEBASKET. Push in on the back of the bo where a SMILING PSYCHOLOGIST is pictured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits in a well decorated Psychologist's Office. Acro from Will sits the same PSYCHOLOGIST, HENRY LIPKIN (40),  from the book. They are in mid-session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I love stock-car racin'.  That Dale Ernhart's real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know Will, and I know, what  you need to be doing. You have a  gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could work the pit maybe, but I  could never drive like Dale Ernhart--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a quality -- something you  were born with, that you have no  control over -- and you are, in a  sense, hiding that by becoming a  janitor. And I'm not saying that's  wrong. I'm friends with the janitor  that works in my building.  He's  been to my house for dinner. As a  matter of fact I did some free  consultation for "Mike" -- that's  not his real name. That's in my book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I read your book. "Mike" had  the same problems as "Chad" the  stockbroker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The pressures you feel, and  again, I am neither labeling nor  judging them, are keeping you from  fulfilling your potential -- you're  in a rut. So stop the Tom Foolery --  the Shenanigan's, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, your not getting off that easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but, I mean you know... I do  other things. That no one knows about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what, Will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go places, I interact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What places?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certain, clubs. (beat) Like, Paradise. It's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gives the Psychologist a furtive look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that feeling when you can  take your shirt off and really dance. (beat) When the music owns you. Do you  understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find it hard to hide the fact  that you're gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I read your book. I talked to  you. It's just something I know to  be true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very presumptuous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, two seconds ago you were ready  to give me a jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little laugh) Well, I'm sorry to disappoint you,  but I'm married and I have two  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you do. You probably got a  real nice house, nice car -- your  book's a best seller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting defensive, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, man. I don't care if you're  putting from the rough. There are  solid arguments that some of the  greatest people in history were gay;  Alexander the Great, Caesar,  Shakespeare, Oscar Wilde, Napoleon,  Gertrude Stein, not to mention Danny  Terrio, not many straight men can  dance like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is "Danny Terrio?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wanna hit "Ramrod," take your  shot. Take some pride in it. You go  to church? So fuckin' what, God loves  you.  I mean, Christ. A guy as well  known as you? By the time you put  your disguise on and skulk out of  the house Sunday nights you probably  look like "Inspector Clouseau."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Psychologist calmly packs his things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can see this is pointless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting defensive... Henry.  And hey, chief -- tell the wife, at  least.  Christ, set her free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shrink gets up and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' hypocrite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Psychologist comes walking out, much to the surprise Lambeau and Tom who have been waiting in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Psychologist keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You know what, Gerry? This is  why I don't do pro-bono anymore.  It's not worth it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the time. I'm going on  national television this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Henry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He [Henry] is out the door. Lambeau looks to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is in Lambeau's office. Lambeau is at the board, wor on a diagram as Tom takes notes. Will seems disinterested

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rectangle is subdivided into  rectangles. One edge of an inner  rectangle is an integer. Can you  prove that one edge of the larger  rectangle is an integer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an integer proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Hey, look buddy my time's almost  up. You want me to sit here for an  hour and write it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau says nothing. Will gets up and goes to the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll give you the key steps to  it but I'm not gonna do the whole  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau keeps smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a monumental waste of  time, wouldn't it, Will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to know so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau rises and goes to the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're thinking too hard. What if I  did this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws a vertical line through the diagram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what if I do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws a horizontal line through the diagram. He hands  Will the chalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever played checkers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will realizes what Lambeau is getting at. In a flash he s drawing lines through the diagram, energized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You color-code it. Half-red, half- black.  If that's an integer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau steps in, writing with him [Will].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-red, half-black--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --that?--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Half-red, half-black--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --That edge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An integer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two stop. They are silent for a moment. Like two  gunfighters after a duel, they put down the chalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks his watch) It would appear we got that proof in  under the wire after all. It's not  how hard you look at things, young  man, it's the way you look at them.  If you take aim before you fire, you  will find the most difficult problems  become, quite literally, child's  play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gets his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, you've managed to offend four  of my colleagues so much that they  refused to come back. You're meeting  with the leading hypnotist in the  country next week and Tom and I plan  to sit in on the sessions, so I expect  you to behave appropriately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits in a chair across from Lambeau and the HYPNOTIS Lambeau's assistant, TOM (33) takes notes. The Hypnotist  makes small talk with Lambeau, who checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we start the, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, when do I get my hypnosis? You  guys been talkin' for twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Will. We'll get to that. But  first, why don't you go to sleep for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He SNAPS HIS FINGERS and instantly Will's head goes BACK his EYES CLOSE. The Hypnotist gives Lambeau a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind standing on one leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gets up and stands on one leg. Lambeau is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is reclining, eyes closed, in a trance-like state. T mood is more serious now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you're in your bed, Will. Now  how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin's in my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a small figure, hoverin'  over me. Gettin' closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will flinches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a safe place, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's touching me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau makes a sound. The Hypnotist shushes him [Lambeau with his [Hypnotist's] finger. Tom returns to his note-ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it touching you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down there. (indicating genitals) And I'm nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to be nervous, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau and the Therapist trade looks. This is working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm not ready. (calming) But the figure tells me everything's  gonna be all right. 'Cause the  figure's a Libra too. And we start  dancin' and it's beautiful--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will breaks into song at full volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "SKY ROCKETS IN FLIGHT!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Oh Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hypnotist gets up and starts heading towards the door Will is still singing from "Sky Rockets."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Barry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have better ways to spend my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is gone. Will stops singing, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for God's sake, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! You're not pinnin' this  one on me. He left, I wanted to talk  to him for another twenty minutes. I  was havin' fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to cooperate with these  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, that guy was a fuckin' piece  of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gets up and adopts a hypnotic persona in front of  Lambeau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spooky voice) Look into my eyes. I don't need  therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... don't forget to get another  therapist for next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is out the door. Lambeau turns to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called Mel Weintraub this morning,  to check for availability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is somebody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my roommate in college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is SEAN MAGUIRE'S "Dying and Bereavement" class.  Emblazoned on the door is "room 101." While the lecture h could hold sixty students, there are less than fifteen he today. Sean Maguire lectures to the class in a resigned tone. Ti of teaching, tired of life, he finds himself resigned to tedium of teaching core classes to an indifferent student body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing trust is the most  important component in making  breakthroughs with a patient. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN'S only response is an empty stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep up the good work, Maureen.  Vinnie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VINNIE looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because trust is an important thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bullshit me, Vinnie. Didn't  your brother give you the notes?  Okay. If a patient doesn't trust you  then they won't feel safe enough to  be honest with you -- then there's  no point to them being in therapy.  It's like saying -- "Fine, come here  and don't tell me a thing but go  home feeling like you're doing  something about your problems -- and  give me my fifty bucks before you  leave will ya'!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the room for approval. No one is listenin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't help them trust you --  then there's no way you'll ever get  them to sleep with you. And that  should be the goal of any good  therapist. Insecure women, you know...  nail 'em when they're vulnerable,  that's always been my motto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students look up, somewhat stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I got Vinnie's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. Sean starts to resume his lecture, when he noti LAMBEAU standing in the back of the room. There is an awk moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) Well, it seems we're in the presence  of greatness. Professor Gerald Lambeau  is a Field's Medal winner.  Combunatorial Mathematics. 1986.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students stare blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Field's Medal is the Nobel Prize  for math. (beat) But it's only given out every four  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's all for today. Try and  get through Fernald by Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class starts to pack up and file out. Lambeau approac Sean who steps down from the lectern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there someplace we can talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Skylar on their first date. They watch a street  MAGICIAN doing tricks with a rabbit. The guy's tricks are pretty good, but his on-stage persona could use some work He is incessantly repeating the phrase "this is the rabbi the rabbit really does the tricks." Will gives Skylar a l and they move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Skylar walk into the small shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, it was just kind of  the boring suburban thing. Private  school, Harvard, and now Med. School. (Beat) I actually figured out that at the  end of it, my brain will be worth a  quarter of a million dollars. I  shouldn't have told you that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet your parents were happy to  pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was happy to pay. I inherited the  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Harvard gettin' all that money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanford. I'm leaving in June after  I graduate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you just want to use me and go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm gonna experiment on you  for my anatomy class, then go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, fine. (beat) Want to see my magic trick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, pulls out a bulging HANDFUL OF CARAMELS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm gonna make all these caramels  disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will goes into all manner of hocus-pocus theatrics. Then  shakes his hand wildly. The trick doesn't pan out and the caramels go flying all over the store. Skylar laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works better when I have my rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau and Sean share a table at this exclusive restaura Sean seems slightly out of place in his wrinkled sport co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see you at the reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were missed. (beat) How long has it been since we've  seen each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since Nancy died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, that damn conference--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got your card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRY COOK hands Will and Skylar a pair of CHEESEBURGERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen Annie Hall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's this part of the movie  that's about how there's always this  tension on a first date where both  people are thinking about what's  going to happen with the whole 'good  night kiss' thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't 'date' that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) You know what I mean. I know you've  at least thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I haven't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you have. You were thinking you  were gonna get a good night kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock protest) No I wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was kinda' hopin' to get a "good  night laid" but... I'll take a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I was hoping to get a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't we just get it out of  the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them have cheeseburger in their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss, mouths full of burger. It's nice. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That had to be the worst good night  kiss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look lady, I'm just here for  the free food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I spent all my money on those  caramels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau and Sean, having finished their meal. Lambeau has been pitching Sean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been busy, Gerry. I got a full  schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid's special, Sean. I've never  seen anything like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much free time, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of a man named  Ramanujan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was alive over a hundred years  ago.  He was Indian. Dots, not  feathers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean finishes the joke. Lambeau chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this Ramanujan lived in a tiny  hut in India. No formal education,  no access to other works. But he  came across an old math book and  from this basic text he was able to  extrapolate theories that had baffled  mathematicians for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he mailed it to Hardy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Sean. He mailed it to  a professor at Cambridge who  immediately recognized the brilliance  in his work and brought Ramanujan to  England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he contracted pneumonia and  died at a young age--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They worked together for the remainder  of their lives, producing some of  the most exciting math theory ever  done.  Ramanujan's genius was  unparalleled, Sean. This boy is like  that. But he's very defensive and I  need someone who can get through to  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need someone with your kind of  background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My kind of background?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from the same neighborhood.  South Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's from Southie? How many people  did you try before you came to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks squarely at  Sean) Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean gives a slight, knowing smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Barry, Henry, Rick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Rick? You didn't send him to  Rick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just meet with the boy once a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we do it at my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter comes with the CHECK. Each man reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of the red-brick campus. Planes land at nearby Logan airport. Will walks up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean's office is comfortable. Books are stacked against t wall. There is a PAINTING on the wall behind Sean. Sean i seated behind a desk. Lambeau sits in a chair in the back the room, next to Tom. A long beat passes, they wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any vulnerability he senses, he'll  exploit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a poker game with this young  man.  Don't let him see what you've  got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean nods. Will walks in. Everyone stands to greet Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Will. Any trouble finding the  place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, this is Sean Maguire. Sean,  Will Hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean and Will nod. An awkward moment as the four men stan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's let the healing begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau is slightly embarrassed. Sean smiles at Will's jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you excuse us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau looks at Sean, surprised. Sean's stare is unwaver After an awkward moment, Lambeau goes, leaving Sean and W alone. Will doesn't look at Sean for more than a second. seems more interested in the room. There is a long silenc as Sean watches Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Will. I'm Sean Maguire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smile crosses Will's face as he walks to his chair and  sits. He lights a cigarette. Sean continues to watch him. Final

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you from in Southie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you buy all these books retail,  or do you send away for like a "shrink  kit" that comes with all these volumes  included?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you read all these books, Will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating a shelf) How about the ones on that shelf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will's eyes flicker up to the shelf for an instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I read those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here for a fuckin' book  report.  They're your books, why  don't you read 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have taken you a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it did take me a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean says this with pride. His determined stare and confi manner catch Will a bit off guard. Will rises from his ch and goes to the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at book) "A History of the United States,  Volume I." If you want to read a  real history book, read Howard Zinn's  "A People's History of the United  States." That book will knock you on  your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Noam Chomsky's  "Manufacturing Consent?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people baffle me. You spend all  this money on beautiful, fancy books--  and they're the wrong fuckin' books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever blows your hair back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will returns to his chair. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating cigarette) Guy your age shouldn't smoke so much. Stunt your growth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. It really gets in the  way of my jazzercizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean does not seem at all affected by Will's attitude. He remains behind the big desk with almost half a smile on h face. Will is aware of Sean's confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nautilus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free weights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Me too. What do you bench?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gets up again and moves around his chair to Sean's  painting. It is a picture of an old sailboat in a tremend storm -- by no means a masterpiece. Will studies it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You paint this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Do you paint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crayons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a real piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what you really think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor color composition, lousy use of  space. But that shit doesn't really  concern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The color here, see how dark it is?  It's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're one step away from  cutting your ear off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, "Starry Night" time, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever heard the saying, "any port  in a storm?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, how 'bout "still waters run  deep"-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Well, maybe that means you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe what mea--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you were in the middle of a  storm, a big fuckin' storm -- the  waves were crashing over the bow,  the Goddamned mast was about to snap,  and you were crying for the harbor.  So you did what you had to do, to  get out.  Maybe you became a  psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should be a patient and  sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you married the wrong woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it isn't it? You married the  wrong woman. She leave you? Was she  bangin' someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean is walking slowly towards Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are the seas now, D--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a flash, Sean has Will by the throat. Will is helpless

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ever disrespect my wife  again... I will end you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will walks out of Sean's office past Lambeau and Tom who sitting in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean stands behind his desk in his office, still very muc on edge. Lambeau walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, Sean. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause, Sean is staring at his painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
