dialogues.text: I'll understand if you don't want to  meet with him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday, four o'clock. Make sure  the kid is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Skylar sit in the stands watching the dogs run.  They ad lib teasing one another about England, Ireland, a America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You grew up around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far from here, South Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty boring, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you have a great family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, nothing special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a lot of brothers and  sisters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have a lot of brothers and  sisters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Irish Catholic. What do you  think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't believe me if I told  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will shakes his head. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have twelve big brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup, you're lookin' at lucky thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your house must have been a zoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was great. There was always someone  to play with, give you advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know all their names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course I do, they're my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marky, Ricky, Danny, Terry, Mikey,  Davey, Timmy, Tommy, Joey, Robby,  Johnny, and Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Do you keep in touch with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time. We all live in Southie.  I live with three of them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skylar smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we pan across Sean's small apartment, we find it strew with dirty clothes and the sink full of dishes. Although, it weren't for the clutter, the place would feel pretty b A framed SPORTS ILLUSTRATED cover featuring a screaming L Bird and entitled "CELTIC PRIDE" hangs on the wall. Sean  sits at the table next to another nearly empty bottle of  BUSHMILL'S IRISH WHISKEY. He is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will strolls into the office. Sean is waiting there behin his desk. He seems different. More calm. Will and Sean st at each other for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You again. How the paintin' coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean and Will sit in the bleachers at the mostly empty pa They look out over a small pond, in which a group of  schoolchildren on a field trip ride the famous Swan Boats

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's with this place? You have  a swan fetish? Is this something  you'd like to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about what you said  to me the other day, about my  painting. I stayed up half the night  thinking about it and then something  occurred to me and I fell into a  deep peaceful sleep and haven't  thought about you since. You know  what occurred to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just a boy. You don't have  the faintest idea what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never been out of Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if I asked you about art you could  give me the skinny on every art book  ever written... Michelangelo? You  know a lot about him I bet. Life's  work, criticisms, political  aspirations. But you couldn't tell  me what it smells like in the Sistine  Chapel. You've never stood there and  looked up at that beautiful ceiling.  And if I asked you about women I'm  sure you could give me a syllabus of  your personal favorites, and maybe  you've been laid a few times too. But you couldn't tell me how it feels  to wake up next to a woman and be  truly happy. If I asked you about  war you could refer me to a bevy of  fictional and non-fictional material,  but you've never been in one. You've  never held your best friend's head  in your lap and watched him draw his  last breath, looking to you for help.  And if I asked you about love I'd  get a sonnet, but you've never looked  at a woman and been truly vulnerable.  Known that someone could kill you  with a look. That someone could rescue  you from grief. That God had put an  angel on Earth just for you.  And  you wouldn't know how it felt to be  her angel. To have the love be there  for her forever. Through anything,  through cancer. You wouldn't know  about sleeping sitting up in a  hospital room for two months holding  her hand and not leaving because the  doctors could see in your eyes that  the term "visiting hours" didn't  apply to you. And you wouldn't know  about real loss, because that only  occurs when you lose something you  love more than yourself, and you've  never dared to love anything that  much. I look at you and I don't see  an intelligent confident man, I don't  see a peer, and I don't see my equal.  I see a boy. Nobody could possibly  understand you, right Will? Yet you  presume to know so much about me  because of a painting you saw.  You  must know everything about me.  You're  an orphan, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will nods quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I would presume to know  the first thing about who you are  because I read "Oliver Twist?" And I  don't buy the argument that you don't  want to be here, because I think you  like all the attention you're getting.  Personally, I don't care. There's  nothing you can tell me that I can't  read somewhere else.  Unless we talk  about your life. But you won't do  that. Maybe you're afraid of what  you might say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean stands,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Chuckie doing demo at the site. They throw  cinderblocks out a window into a pile. They are filthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pounds South Boston. Chuckie sits with the Cadillac  fiddling, humming to the radio. Morgan and Billy sit in t back, sharing a case of beer. Will is at a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will hangs up and runs back to the car, soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one. I didn't have the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, retarded? You went all  the way out there in the rain and  you didn't have the number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was your mother's 900 number.  I just ran out of quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. Chuckie pulls away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we get off mothers, I just  got off yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long moment of silence in response to Morgan's attempt at levity. Then laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a pretty funny guy. Here,  have a nickel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy WHIPS his EMPTY BEER CAN off of Morgan's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep fuckin' with me. Watch what  happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch what happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits across from Sean completely silent and takes ou pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will puts the cigarettes away. Sean stares at Will and  occasionally at the clock. Sean continues to check the cl on the wall. It is the only clock in the room and it is B Will. Their hour is almost up. CLOSE ON: WILL'S EYES INTERCUT WITH THE CLOCK. He is counting seconds. As the second hand crosses the tw Will stands up and walks out, leaving Sean alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau and Sean walk down the hallway after the session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean "he didn't talk?"  You sat there for an hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he just sat there and counted  the seconds until the session was  over. It was pretty impressive,  actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would he do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To show me he doesn't have to talk  to me if he doesn't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what is this? Some kind of staring  contest between two kids from the  "old neighborhood?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't talk first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie drops Will off at his apartment, watches him [Wil walk up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie pulls up to the curb and walks up the steps to Wi front door. After a beat, Will emerges. They get back in  [the car].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Chuckie at work. Chuckie shows Will how to be a  man. INT. L STREET BAR & GRILLE, SOUTH BOSTON -- NIGHT The bar is a bit more crowded than usual. Will and Chucki walk back to their table, carrying beers. They pass a tab of GIRLS, local regulars getting just as bombed as the gu These girls are a little overdone. Too much make-up, too  much hairspray, and too much body for such tight outfits. One of the girls, KRYSTYN, smiles at Will who seems subdu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin', Krystyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass the table of girls. Chuckie looks at one, ruefu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get on Cathy last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie turns back to one of the girls, calling out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy! Why didn't you give me none  of your twat last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl at the table, CATHY, holds up her PINKY FINGER and smiles -- revealing a mouthful of MISSING TEETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you and your Irish curse,  Chuckie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's missin' teeth, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will nods, not really into it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus, it's like, five to two Morgan  ends up marryin' her. There's only  so many times you can bang your  friend's future wife...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get to the table. Will's heart just isn't in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm takin' off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're goin' late night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Lambeau work together at the board. They communi non-verbally as they collaborate on a problem. After a  particularly amusing series of numbers, they share a look and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Sean sit in silence. A long moment passes. Sean  casually reclines in his chair, disinterested. Will restl looks around the room and then back to Sean. An odd half  smile crosses Sean's face. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I was on this plane once.  And I'm sittin' there and the captain  comes on and is like "we'll be  cruising at 35,000 feet," and does  his thing, then he puts the mike  down but forgets to turn it off.  Then he says "man, all I want right  now is a blow-job and a cup of  coffee."  So the stewardess goes  runnin' up towards the cock-pit to  tell him the mike's still on, and  this guy in the back of the plane  goes "don't forget the coffee!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You've never been on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but the joke's better if I  tell it in the first person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been laid you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? You got a lady now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I went on a date last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, are you going out again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't called her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, you are an amateur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm doing. She's different  from the other girls I met. We have  a really good time. She's smart,  beautiful, fun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Christ, call her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? So I can realize she's not so  smart. That she's boring. You don't  get it. Right now she's perfect, I  don't want to ruin that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And right now you're perfect too.  Maybe you don't want to ruin that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think that's a great  philosophy Will, that way you can go  through your entire life without  ever having to really know anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean looks directly at Will, who looks away. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife used to turn the alarm clock  off in her sleep. I was late for  work all the time because in the  middle of the night she'd roll over  and turn the damn thing off.  Eventually I got a second clock and  put it under my side of the bed, but  it got to where she was gettin' to  that one too. She was afraid of the  dark, so the closet light was on all  night. Thing kept me up half the  night.  Eventually I'd fall asleep,  out of sheer exhaustion and not wake  up when I was supposed to cause she'd  have already gotten to my alarms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will smiles, Sean takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's been dead two years, Will.  And when I think about her, those  are the things I think about most.  Little idiosyncrasies that only I  knew about.  Those made her my wife.  And she had the goods on me too.  Little things I do out of habit.  People call these things imperfections  Will. It's just who we are. And we  get to choose who we're going to let  into out weird little worlds. You're  not perfect. And let me save you the  suspense, this girl you met isn't  either. The question is, whether or  not you're perfect for each other.   You can know everything in the world,  but the only way you're findin' that  one out is by giving it a shot. You  sure won't get the answer from an  old fucker like me. And even if I  did know, I wouldn't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will smiles. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You told me every other  fuckin' thing. You talk more than  any shrink I ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach this shit, I didn't say I  knew how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever think about gettin'  remarried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hence, the word remarried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I think that's a wonderful  philosophy, Sean. That way you can  go through the rest of your life  without having to really know anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Sean smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is waiting outside the door for someone to come out so he can go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to Skylar's dorm is partially open. Will stands  outside while Skylar remains on the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I been real busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were busy? You know, I really  was waiting for you to call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm sorry. Give me another  crack at it. Let me take you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have called. I have an "O- chem" lab due tomorrow and it's  impossible. (beat) It's not an excuse dummy. I want to  go out with you. But look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up her Lab. Will glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you bring the caramels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits in an outdoor cafe, thinking. After a beat, he  leans over to two students working at a nearby table, bor a pen and paper and starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is a solitary figure strolling across the lawn. He s at Skylar's dorm and knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She emerges. He hands her the paper he was working on. It her O-chem lab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't wait till tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't your mother ever tell you not  to look a gift horse in the mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to understand this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going into surgery tomorrow  are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's go have some fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a smile, she relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean and Will in session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? How'd the date go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still counsel veterans? (beat) I read your book last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave that up when my wife got sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you didn't write anything  else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I didn't write anything else 'cause  nobody, including most of my  colleagues bothered to read the first  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've read you colleagues. Your  book was good, Sean. (beat) All those guys were in your platoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to that guy from  Kentucky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lon? He got married. He has a kid. I  kind of lost touch with him after  Nancy got sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever wonder what your life  would be like if you never met your  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Do I wonder if I'd be better  off if I never met my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will starts to clarify his question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's okay. It's an important  question. 'Cause you'll have your  bad times, which wake you up to the  good stuff you weren't paying  attention to.  And you can fail, as  long as you're trying hard. But  there's nothing worse than regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't regret meetin' your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Because of the pain I feel now?  I have regrets Will, but I don't  regret a singel day I spent with  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you know she was the one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 21, 1975. Game six of the  World Series. Biggest game in Red  Sox history, Me and my friends slept  out on the sidewalk all night to get  tickets. We were sitting in a bar  waiting for the game to start and in  walks this girl.  What a game that  was. Tie game in the bottom of the  tenth inning, in steps Carlton Fisk,  hit a long fly ball down the left  field line. Thirty-five thousand  fans on their feet, screamin' at the  ball to stay fair. Fisk is runnin'  up the baseline, wavin' at the ball  like a madman. It hits the foul pole,  home run. Thirty-five thousand people  went crazy. And I wasn't one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was havin' a drink with my future  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed Pudge Fisk's homerun to  have a drink with a woman you had  never met?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So wait a minute. The Red Sox haven't  won a World Series since nineteen  eighteen, you slept out for tickets,  games gonna start in twenty minutes,  in walks a girl you never seen before,  and you give your ticket away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have seen this girl. She  lit up the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if Helen of Troy walked  into that bar! That's game six of  the World Series!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what kind of friends are these?  They let you get away with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just slid my ticket across the  table and said "sorry fellas, I gotta  go see about a girl."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I gotta go see about a girl"? What  did they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could see that I meant it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kiddin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Will, I'm not kiddin' you. If I  had gone to see that game I'd be in  here talkin' abouta girl I saw at a  bar twenty years ago. And how I always  regretted not goin' over there and  talkin' to her. I don't regret the  eighteen years we were married. I  don't regret givin' up counseling  for six years when she got sick. I  don't regret being by her side for  the last two years when things got  real bad. And I sure as Hell don't  regret missing that damn game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Will is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would have been nice to catch that  game though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking) Well hell, I didn't know Pudge was  gonna hit the home run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: INT LAMBEAU'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The office is more crowded than usual. TOM and THREE of  LAMBEAU'S COLLEAGUES including the esteemed ALEXANDER PEK are in the room. Will sits at a work-station which projec a proof of his [Will's] onto the chalkboard. Lambeau stan beside the projected image at the board arguing with Peke a foreign mathematician. The image is of a Ramses graph b tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander, I know your theory. The  boy is updating, he's strategy  stealing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a Ramses graph on the binary  tree--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --But what he's doing, he's attaching  an edge to the adjacent vertex. He  can always failsafe to either side--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maker can. This is not new, Gerry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pekec starts writing lines beside Will's proof on the boa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can always garbage out (writes frantically) All the way to "N" to the minus one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's a limit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limit is not found! (turns to Will) The limit is not found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can always go to the other  side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no proof--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau can no longer contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maker builds "K" to the "N." N is  three to the K times--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I wrote it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to Will who places his proof on the projector. image is cast over their faces. It reads: As Pekec reads and the realization dawns on him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just simpler this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau turns with satisfaction to an understanding Pekec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander, your theory is changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Skylar in her room, post coital. They are wrappe in a sheet. Will is absent-mindedly playing the memory ga SIMON. The pattern grows increasingly complex. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do we always stay here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause it's nicer than my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your friends? Or your  brothers? When do I get to meet them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't come over here that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can make it to South Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah, it's kind of a hike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it me you're hiding from them or  the other way around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. We'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometime. I don't know. Next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I said I wouldn't sleep with  you again until you let me meet your  friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say... (reaches for phone) It's only four in the mornin', they're  prob'ly up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. Stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You men are shameful. If you're not  thinking of your wiener then you're  acting on its behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then on behalf of my wiener, I'd  like to ask for an advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. L STREET BAR & GRILLE -- LATER Skylar and Will sit together along with Will's gang. The  boys are considerably drunk, but it makes for good  entertainment. Everyone here is having fun including Sylar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, I can't believe you brought  Skylar here when we're all wrecked.  What's she gonna think about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Morgan. It's a real rarity  that we'd be out drinkin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been shit faced for like two  weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great, tell her that! Now she  really thinks we're problem drinkers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks? That's nothin'. My Uncle  Marty? Will knows him. That guy  fuckin' drinks like you've never  seen! One night he was drivin' back  to his house on I-93 -- Statie pulls  him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's tryin' to walk the line -- but  he can't even fuckin' stand up, and  so my uncle's gonna spend a night in  jail.  Just then there's this fuckin'  BOOM like fifty yards down the road.  Some guy's car hit a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was probably drunker than  my Uncle, who fuckin' knows? So the  cop goes "Stay here" And he goes  runnin' down the highway to deal  with the other crash. So, my Uncle  Marty's standin' on the side of the  road for a little while, and he's so  fuckin' lit, that he forgets what  he's waitin' for. So he goes, "Fuck  it." He gets in his car and drives  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So in the morning, there's a knock  on the door it's the Statie. So my  Uncle's like, "Is there a problem?"  And the Statie's like "I pulled you  over and you took off."  And my  Uncle's like "I never seen you before  in my life, I been home all night  with my kids." And Statie's like  "Let me get in your garage!" So he's  like "All right, fine." He takes  around the garage and opens the door -- and the Statie's cruiser is in my  Uncle's garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way! You're kiddin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he was so hammered that he drove  the police cruiser home. Fuckin'  lights and everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your Uncle get arrested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuckin' Trooper was so embarrassed  he didn't do anything. The fuckin'  guy had been drivin' around in my  Uncle's car all night lookin' for  the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is laughing. Skylar speaks above the din.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was this Irish guy, walking  down the beach one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has everyone's attention. Will is nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he comes across a bottle, and  this Genie pops out. The genie turns  to the Irishman and says -- "You've  released me from my prison, so I'll  grant you three wishes." The Irish  guy thinks for a minute and says  "What I really want is a pint of  Guiness that never empties."  And --  POOF! A bottle appears. He slams it  down, and -- lo and behold -- it  fills back up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C/U of Will. Hoping the joke pans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the Irish guy can't believe  it. He drinks it again, and again --  BOOM!  It fills back up. So, while  the Irish guy is marveling at his  good fortune, The Genie is getting  impatient, because it's hot and he  wants to get on with his freedom. He  says "Let's go, you have two more  wishes." The Irish guy slams his  drink again, it fills back up, he's  still amazed. The Genie can't take  it anymore. He says "Buddy, I'm  boiling out here. What are your other  two wishes?" (beat) The Irish guy looks at his drink,  looks at the Genie and says... "I  guess I'll have two more of these."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang erupts with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing no one's Irish  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Irish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie, Will look at Morgan, baffled. EXT. L STREET BAR & GRILLE -- LATER Everyone is walking out, saying good-bye. Chuckie goes ov to Will and Skylar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came by, changed my  opinion of Harvard people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya' Chuckie. I had fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie heads towards Will to say goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what the fuck you're  doin'.  You're givin' us a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I look like, Al Cowlins? (seriously) You want to take my car, drop her  off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was countin' on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're walkin' bitch, Will's takin'  the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan mumbles something and staggers off. Billy follows  with an indifferent shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get too slap-happy, you're  takin' me home first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Chuck. It's kinda outta  the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just 'cause you don't have to sleep  in the one room palace, don't start  thinkin' you're bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Will) I thought you said you'd show me  your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, not tonight. Not any other  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows, once you see that shit-hole he's gettin' droppe like a bad habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to meet your brothers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie gives Will a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all sleepin' now. (a beat, to Chuckie) Let me get those keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cocktail party is underway. Professors mingle with representatives from high tech companies. Lambeau stands  holding a drink and surrounded by several RECRUITERS.  Apparently he's the star of the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want to know, Gerry, is when  we get to meet this wonder-boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still working together, the  boy's a little rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got our share of eccentric  geniuses at Tri-tech. We know how to  deal with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not exaggerating, Gerry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I exaggerating in nineteen eighty- four when I told you I'd win the  Field's medal within two years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case the boy could run  shipping for us, routing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say he doesn't have a diploma,  but we'llВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to see a driver's  license.  I can think of three  departments right now that he could  head up for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease, gentlemen. We're looking  carefully at all our options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Gerry. Close to the vest. (gives him his card) Good luck with these vultures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy's Tap is a local watering hole, not unlike the L St Bar. Sean is at the bar, telling a joke to TIMMY (45) the owner of the place, and several other REGULARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she goes runnin' up the aisle and  I figure "fuck it" and I yell out  "don't forget the coffee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men erupt in laughter. MARTY, one of the regulars pip up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit! You didn't say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy and Sean exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Marty. It's a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau enters, a bit overdressed in his sport coat and t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry! Any trouble finding the place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy this is Gerry, an old friend  of mine. We went to college together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we get a couple of sandwiches? (beat, smiles) Put it on my tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean heads towards a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever plan on payin' your tab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls out lottery  ticket) I got the winning numbers right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the jackpot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that'll cover it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau follows [Sean]. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here quite a bit, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You moved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been here a couple years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to talk about Will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like it's going well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, have you talked to him at all  about his future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't really gotten into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should. My phone's been  ringing off the hook with job offers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jobs doing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutting edge mathematics. Think tanks. The kind of place where a mind like  Will's is given free reign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Gerry, that there's  interest -- But I'm not sure he's  ready for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, I really don't think you  understand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What don't I understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy comes over with the sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Timmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Timmy. Could you help us? We're trying to settle a bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard of Jonas Salk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, cured polio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've heard of Albert Einstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy smiles. Gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Gerald Lambeau? Ever heard  of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay thank you, Timmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who won the bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Timmy leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't about me. I'm nothing  compared to this young man. (beat) Sean, in 1905 there were hundreds of  Professors who were renowned for  their study of the universe. But it  was a 26-year-old Swiss Patent clerk,  doing physics in his spare time, who  changed the world, Sean. Can you  imagine if Einstein had given that  up? Or gotten drunk with his buddies  in Vienna every night? All of us  would have lost something. And I'm  quite sure Timmy never would have  heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a little dramatic, Gerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sean. This boy has that gift. He  just hasn't got the direction. We  can give that to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He married his cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Einstein. Had two marriages, both  trainwrecks.  The guy never saw his  kids, one of whom, I think, ended up  in an asylum- possible Unabomber  addition--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Sean? That's exactly not  the point. No one remembers that.  They--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boy can make contributions to  the world. We can help him do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just... take it easy, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't know what else I can  say.  I'm not sitting at home every  night, twisting my mustache and  hatching a plan to ruin the boy's  life. But it's important to start  early. I was doing advanced  mathematics at eighteen and it still  took me twenty-three years to do  something worthy of a Field's medal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he doesn't care about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, this is important. And it's  above personal rivalry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute, Gerry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no you hear me out, Sean. This  young man is a true prodigy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personal rivalry? I'm not getting  back at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you took one road and I took  another. That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it Gerry? 'Cause I don't think  it's fine with you. Give him time to  figure out what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a wonderful theory, Sean. It  worked wonders for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Lambeau gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, I came here today out of  courtesy.  I wanted to keep you in  the loop. As we speak the boy is in  a meeting I set up for him over at  Tri-tech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three well dressed TRI-TECH EXECUTIVES sit around a confe table, which is littered with promotional brochures. The  executives exchange a confused look. One of them speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative) Well, Will, I'm not exactly sure  what you mean, we've already offered  you a position..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut to reveal: Chuckie sitting across from the executives hair combed down, wearing his Sunday best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since this is obviously not my first  time in such altercations, let me  say this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie rubs the tips of his fingers together, indicating "cash." The executives are baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we can do this the easy way or  the hard way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The executives are completely blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the current time I am looking at  a number of different fields from  which to disseminate which offer is  most pursuant aid to my benefit. (a beat) What do you want? What do I want?  What does anybody want? Leniency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --These circumstances are mitigated. Right now. They're mitigated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie puts his hands up, as if getting a vibe from the  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie points to the third executive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third executive is baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A retainer. Nobody in this town works  without a retainer. You think you  can find someone who does, you have  my blessin'. But I think we all know  that person isn't going to represent  you as well as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, our offer starts you at eighty- four thousand a year, plus benefits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retainer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want us to give you cash right  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allegedly, what I am saying is your  situation will be concurrently  improved if I had two hundred sheets  in my pocket right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The executives exchange looks and go for their wallets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I... Larry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have about seventy-three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take a check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now... what do you think I am,  a juvenile? You don't got any money  on you right now. You think I'm gonna  take a check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine, John, I can cover the  rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, you know. (turns to #1) He knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie stands up and takes the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to exec #1) You're suspect. I don't know what  your reputation is, but after the  shit you tried to pull today, you  can bet I'll be looking into it. Any  conversations you want to have with  me heretofore, you can have with my  attorney. Gentlemen, keep your ears  to the grindstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Skylar sit in the open courtyard of this Harvard Square eatery. Skylar is working on another O-chem lab. W sits across from her, slightly bored watching her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to take a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, give me a peek and we'll go  to the battin' cages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important that I learn this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it important to you? If I  inherited all that money, the only  thing important to me would be workin'  on my swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're rich. What do you have to  worry about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich? I have an inheritance. It's  two hundred and fifty thousand  dollars.  That's exactly what it'll  cost me, minus about five hundred  bucks, to go all the way through med  school. This is what I'm doing with  that money. I could have done anything  I wanted. I could have expanded my  wardrobe, substantially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead you're going to bust your  ass for five years so you can be  broke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, so I can be a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Will nods. She looks down, then up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Nosey Parker. Let me  ask you a question? Do you have a  photographic memory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. I don't know. How do you  remember your phone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever studied Organic  Chemistry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some, a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody does organic chemistry for  "fun."  It's unnecessary. Especially  for someone like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Someone like you who divides  his time, fairly evenly, between the  batting cages and bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you do that? I can't... I  mean even the smartest people I know,  and we do have a few at Harvard,  have to study- a lot. It's hard. (beat) Listen, Will, if you don't want to  tell me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you play the piano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come one Will. I just want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to explain it to you. So  you play the piano. When you look at  the keys, you see music, you see  Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see "Hot Cross Buns," but okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well all right, Beethoven. He looked  at a piano and saw music. The fuckin'  guy was deaf when he composed the  Ode to Joy. They had to turn him  around to take a bow because he  couldn't hear the crowd going crazy  behind him. Stone deaf. He saw all  of that music in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, do you play the piano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a lick. I look at a piano and I  see black and white keys, three pedals  and a box of wood. Beethoven, Mozart,  they looked at it and it just made  sense to them. They saw a piano and  they could play. I couldn't paint  you a picture, I probably can't hit  the ball out of Fenway Park and I  can't play the piano--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can do my O-chem lab in under  an hour, you can--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it came to stuff like that I  could always just play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skylar is awestruck with admiration for Will, the Robot-p So much so that Skylar has to kiss him, then push him awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it's taken me four  years to meet you and I'm going to  California in two months, Will. (beat) Have you ever been to California? I  bet you'd like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will freezes. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie sits on his couch, watching cartoons in his boxer and a tee-shirt, eating cereal. The doorbell rings. He si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get it, ma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't. He gets up. Opens door. It's Skylar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know where to find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You were the only Sullivan in the  phone book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and I dropped you off here,  remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your house, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie nods and is about to respond when he is interrupt by a nagging shriek from his mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in here, Chuckie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back) Pipe down, Ma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No. This is my mother's house.  I don't live with my mother. I just  stop by, help out. I'm good like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll live. (beat) If she starts yelling again I might  have to run in real quick and beat  her with the stick again but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie, still in his boxers walks with Skylar who is tal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, now this doesn't feel right. (beat) When I made the decision to come  over here it felt right. I had all  these rationalizations... I just  don't understand why Will never tells  me anything, he won't let me get  close to him, he tells me these weird  lies--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You caught that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to find out what was  going on... But now that I'm here it  seems strange, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't have no trousers on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why you're here. Will don't  talk much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what his family's like  or if he doesn't have any brothers,  but he doesn't have to lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know what to say.  Look, I lie to women all the time.  That's just my way. (beat) Last week Morgan brought these girls  down from Roslindale. I told them I  was a cosmonaut. They believed me.  But Will's not usually like that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put some clothes on, Sullivan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can say is; I known Will a  long time -- And I seen him with  every girl he's ever been with. But  I've never seen him like this before,  ever with anyone, like how he is  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Will are sitting waiting for Lambeau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau enters going over a thick proof Will has complete

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is correct. I see you used  Mclullen here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what it's called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --This can't be right. (examining proof) This is going to be very embarrassing. Have you ever considered--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure it's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back) Can I ask you a favor, can we do  this at Sean's from now on? 'Cause I  leave work to come here and the  fuckin' commute is killin' me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, but did you ever think--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right. (a beat, heading out) Take it home with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, what happened at the Tri-tech  meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't go 'cause I had a date.  So I sent my chief negotiator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, on your own time, you can do  what you like. When I set up a  meeting, with my associates, and you  don't show up it reflects poorly on  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't set up any more meetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll cancel every meeting right now. I'll give you a job myself. I just  wanted you to see what was out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't want to spend my life  sittin' around and explaining shit  to people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The least you can do is show me a  little appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates proof) You know how fuckin' easy this is to  me? This is a joke! (crumples proof) And I'm sorry you can't do this. I  really am. 'Cause if you could I  wouldn't be forced to watch you fumble  around and fuck it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, then you'd have more time to  sit around and get drunk. Think of  how many fights you could have been  in by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will turns around reveling that he's lit the PROOF ON FIR Will drops it on the floor. Lambeau drops to his knees an puts it out. He looks up at Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Will. I can't do that  proof and you can. And when it comes  to this there are only twenty people  in the world that can tell the  difference between you and me. But  I'm one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I. (beat) Yes. That's right, Will. Most days I  wish I never met you. Because then I  could sleep at night. I wouldn't  have to walk around with the knowledge  that someone like you was out there.  And I wouldn't have to watch you  throw it all away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau gathers his composure and calmly walks over to th wrinkled proof. He picks it up, smooths it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Skylar lie in bed. Skylar watches Will sleep. Sh gets up and goes to the fridge. Returning to the bed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will? Are you awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me to California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I just do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but how do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause that's a serious thing you're  sayin'. I mean, we might be in  California next week and you could  find out somethin' about me that you  don't like. And you might feel like  "hey this is a big mistake." (getting upset) But you can't take it back, 'cause  you know it's real serious and you  can't take somethin' like that back.  Now I'm in California, 'cause you  asked me to come. But you don't really  want me there. And I'm stuck in  California with someone who really  doesn't want me there and just wishes  they had a take-back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Take-back?" What is that? I don't  want a take-back. I want you to come  to California with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go out to California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, because I have a job here and  two because I live here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Look, Will if you're not in love  with me, you can say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sayin' I'm not in love with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean "What am I afraid  of?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't you come with me? What are  you so scared of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I scared of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what aren't you scared of?   You live in your safe little world  where nobody challenges you and you're  scared shitless to do anything else--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me about my world. You're  the one that's afraid. You just want  to have your little fling with the  guy from the other side of town and  marry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you think--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: some prick from Stanford that your  parents will approve of. Then you'll  sit around with the rest of the upper  crust kids and talk about how you  went slummin' too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I inherited that money when I was  thirteen, when my father died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you have a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! You think I want this?  That money's a burden to me. Every  day I wake up and I wish I could  give that back.  I'd give everything  I have back to spend one more day  with my father. But that's life. And  I deal with it. So don't put that  shit on me. You're the one that's  afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck am I afraid of?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of me. You're afraid  that I won't love you back. And guess  what?  I'm afraid too. But at least  I have the balls to it give it a  shot. At least I'm honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not honest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your twelve brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that what this is about? You  want to hear that I don't really  have any brothers? That I'm a fuckin'  orphan? Is that what you want to  hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Will. I didn't even know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't want to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to hear that I got  cigarettes put out on me when I was  a little kid. That this isn't surgery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will lifts his shirt, revealing a six inch SCAR on his to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to hear that. Don't  tell me you want to hear that shit!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. Did you ever think that  maybe I could help you? That maybe  that's the point, that we're a team?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you want to come in here and  save me? Is that what you want to  do? Do I have a sign that says "save  me" on my back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to "save" you. I just  want to be with you. I love you. I  love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, full of self-loathing, raises his hand to strike he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bullshit me! Don't fuckin'  bullshit me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up to him) You know what I want to hear?  I  want to hear that you don't love me.  If you tell me that, then I'll leave  you alone. I won't ask any questions  and I won't be in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Will looks Skylar dead in the eye. Lowers his han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will leaves pulling on his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits across from two N.S.A. AGENTS, OLIVER DYTRESS a ROBERT TAVANO. These guys are smug, clean cut, gung-ho an looking sharp in twin navy blue suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why do you think I should work  for the National Security Agency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'd be working on the cutting  edge. You'd be exposed to the kind  of technology you couldn't see  anywhere else because we've classified  it. Super string theory, Chaos Math,  Advanced algorithms--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Codebreaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one aspect of what we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, that's what you do. You  handle more than eighty percent of  the intelligence workload. You're  seven times the size of the C.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly right, Will. So the  question as I see it isn't "why should  you work for N.S.A." it's "why  shouldn't you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't I work for the National  Security Agency? That's a tough one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will bites his tongue, trying to make this work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie, Billy, and Will sit in the Sullivan kitchen. Bil cracks open a beer and Chuckie reads the sports page. Bot boys are smoking. Will drinks a beer, distractedly. We he the faint music track and soft moans of a PORNO MOVIE  emanating from a back room. After a beat, Chuckie looks u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan, if you're watchin' pornos in  my mom's room again I'm gonna give  you a fuckin' beatin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, Morgan comes out of the back room, red-face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) What's up guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you beat off at your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a VCR at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will pays no attention to this exchange

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is on pay phone talking to Skylar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to call before you  left. (beat) I'm takin' all these job interviews.  So I won't just be a construction  worker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never cared about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Will. (pause) No take-backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will hangs up. Hold on him for an agonizing beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau is scribbling away at work. Tom is taking notes.  Will is tapping his fingers, waiting for him to finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can... I'm almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skylar stands at the gate, carry-ons in hand. Her flight boarding. She looks for Will over the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will picks up a FRAME from Sean's desk. It is CARLTON FIS BASEBALL CARD. Will has to smile. Lambeau looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you smiling at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Carlton Fisk baseball card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will can see that Lambeau wants more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pudge Fisk. You follow baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final boarding call is announced and the last passeng boards. After a beat, Skylar turns and gets on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, holding the card, reflects for a beat and puts it d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, it's just somethin' Sean  told me. It's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the first part. The rest I  can do at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, the N.S.A. has been calling me  just about every hour. They're very  excited about how the meeting went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau is excited. Will clearly is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits across from Sean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you might be working for Uncle  Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry says the meeting went well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Will has obviously been stewing on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say I'm working at N.S.A. Somebody  puts a code on my desk, something  nobody else can break. So I take a  shot at it and maybe I break it. And  I'm real happy with myself, 'cause I  did my job well.  But maybe that  code was the location of some rebel  army in North Africa or the Middle  East. Once they have that location,  they bomb the village where the rebels  were hiding and fifteen hundred people  I never had a problem with get killed.  (rapid fire) Now the politicians are  sayin' "send in the Marines to secure  the area" 'cause they don't give a  shit. It won't be their kid over  there, gettin' shot. Just like it  wasn't them when their number got  called, 'cause they were pullin' a  tour in the National Guard. It'll be  some guy from Southie takin' shrapnel  in the ass.  And he comes home to  find that the plant he used to work  at got exported to the country he  just got back from. And the guy who  put the shrapnel in his ass got his  old job, 'cause he'll work for fifteen  cents a day and no bathroom breaks.  Meanwhile my buddy from Southie  realizes the only reason he was over  there was so we could install a  government that would sell us oil at  a good price. And of course the oil  companies used the skirmish to scare  up oil prices so they could turn a  quick buck. A cute, little ancillary  benefit for them but it ain't helping  my buddy at two-fifty a gallon. And  naturally they're takin' their sweet  time bringin' the oil back and maybe  even took the liberty of hiring an  alcoholic skipper who likes to drink  seven and sevens and play slalom  with the icebergs and it ain't too  long 'til he hits one, spills the  oil, and kills all the sea-life in  the North Atlantic. So my buddy's  out of work and he can't afford to  drive so he's got to walk to the job  interviews which sucks 'cause the  shrapnel in his ass is givin' him  chronic hemorrhoids.  And meanwhile  he's starvin' 'cause every time he  tries to get a bite to eat the only  blue-plate special they're servin'  is North Atlantic scrod with Quaker  State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'd I think?  I'm holdin' out  for somethin' better. I figure I'll  eliminate the middle man. Why not  just shoot my buddy, take his job  and give it to his sworn enemy, hike  up gas prices, bomb a village, club  a baby seal, hit the hash pipe and  join the National Guard? Christ, I  could be elected President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you're alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a soul-mate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Define that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who challenges you in every  way.  Who takes you places, opens  things up for you. A soul-mate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare, Neitzche, Frost,  O'Connor, Chaucer, Pope, Kant--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me, they're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't give back to them,  Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not without a heater and some serious  smelling salts, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm saying, Will. You'll  never have that kind of relationship  in a world where you're afraid to  take the first step because all you're  seeing are the negative things that  might happen ten miles down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what? You're going to take the  professor's side on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me your line of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about that job. I'm not  saying you should work for the  government. But, you could do anything  you want. And there are people who  work their whole lives layin' brick  so their kids have a chance at the  kind of opportunity you have. What  do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody gets what they ask for, Will. That's a cop-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it a cop-out? I don't see  anythin' wrong with layin' brick,  that's somebody's home I'm buildin'.  Or fixin' somebody's car, somebody's  gonna get to work the next day 'cause  of me. There's honor in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Will. Any man who takes  a forty minute train ride so those  college kids can come in in the  morning and their floors will be  clean and their trash cans will be  empty is an honorable man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Will says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when they get drunk and puke in  the sink, they don't have to see it  the next morning because of you.  That's real work, Will. And there is  honor in that.  Which I'm sure is  why you took the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know why you decided  to sneak around at night, writing on  chalkboards and lying about it. (beat) 'Cause there's no honor in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something you want to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean gets up, goes to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come back when you  have an answer for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you won't answer my questions,  you're wasting my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will loses it, slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean has finally gotten to Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you to lecture me  about life? You fuckin' burnout!  Where's your "soul-mate?!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean lets this play out. Possible "shepard" change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead! She dies and you just cash in  your chips. That's a fuckin' cop- out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been there. I played my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. And you fuckin' lost!   And some people would have the sack  to lose a big hand like that and  still come back and ante up again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Will looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your bullshit. You got an  answer for everybody. But I asked  you a straight question and you can't  give me a straight answer. Because  you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean goes to the door and opens it. Will walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Chuckie take crowbars to a wall. This is what th do for a living. As they routinely hammer away, Will beco more involved in his battle with the wall. Plaster and la fly as Will vents his rage. Chuckie, noticing, stops work and takes a step back, watching Will. Will is oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lambeau and Tom are in his office. Will is nowhere to be  seen. Lambeau is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean, Sean, is that I'm sitting  in your office and the boy isn't  here. (beat) Well, it's ten past three. (beat) An hour and ten minutes late. (beat) Well, if he doesn't show up and I  have to file a report saying he wasn't  here and he goes back to jail, it  won't be on my conscience, Sean. (beat) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Tom picks up a FORM up off the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy was here. He came in, sat  down and we worked together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blank look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came in, sat down, and we worked  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom understands, begins filling out the form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will walks out carrying a brown bag. He is filthy, having just knocked off work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckie is sitting on the hood of his Cadillac, watching  Will across the street. Chuckie is covered in grime as we Will starts walking towards Chuckie. As he draws closer, heaves a can of Budweiser a good thirty yards, to Chuckie who handles it routinely. Will takes a seat next to Chuckie and they crack open the beers. Other workers file out of the site. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
